audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker, excited, declaring, "You've seen nukes explode, you've seen planets explode. Now, you're going to talk about stars exploding!" The clip abruptly cuts to a sound effect of a thunderous explosion, followed by a clip of children's voices, with a male speaker stating, "He does have the eye of the tiger." A male speaker excitedly responds, "Are you sure about that?" The scene shifts back to a lecture-style male speaker discussing the discovery of supernovas in 185 AD in China. The speaker describes supernovas as massive explosions at the end of a star's life cycle and mentions their rarity. The clip concludes with a sound effect similar to the previous explosion.

The clip begins with a single male speaker explaining the difference between a "nova" and a "supernova," in a somewhat lighthearted and informative tone. He describes novae as stars that brighten temporarily and are often caused by white dwarfs in binary systems stealing matter from neighboring stars. He then contrasts this with supernovae, jokingly referring to them as what happens when Michael Bay looks into the night sky.

The clip begins with a male speaker explaining that very large explosions are possible only with high-mass stars, naming "Beetlejuice" and "Canis Majoris". He clarifies that low-mass stars cannot become hot enough to burn carbon, and can only burn hydrogen and helium, before turning into white dwarfs when they run out of fuel. He then asserts that high-mass stars are "different though".

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing high mass stars and nuclear fusion, referencing chemistry class and the periodic table. He uses an informative and somewhat conversational tone, explaining how stars burn through hydrogen and fuse it into helium. There's a slight echo present. Following this discussion, a sound effect resembling an explosion occurs, ending the clip.

The audio clip features one male speaker discussing the fusion process in high-mass stars. The speaker says that the process continues "further on from helium...all the way to iron," and notes that "iron is where things get a bit interesting." The tone is informative and slightly intrigued.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker explaining how fusion becomes impossible in a star because iron is extremely stable. He continues to state that energy cannot be extracted from iron, and once iron shows up in a star's core, it begins losing energy.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing how events happen quickly, referencing stars and extremely high temperatures, photons, splitting elements into lighter parts, and even protons, neutrons, and electrons. The speaker's tone is informative and somewhat excited. Following this, the audio ends with a single, low-frequency rumble sound.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing "photodisintegration" and describing it as "not a fun process for the star." He elaborates on how the core goes through all materials in seconds during the process. He notes that splitting elements requires vast energy, and the star throws all its energy into fission, cooling the core and reducing pressure. His tone is informative and somewhat conversational.

A male speaker describes the composition and collapse of a star, noting only electrons, neutrons, protons, and photons are left. As the star shrinks, the speaker notes photons and electrons are crushed to form neutrons and neutrinos and that the electrons have merged with the protons. The speaker summarizes the process before moving on. He has a scientific and informative tone, and speaks clearly.

The clip starts with a male speaker stating, "in a nutshell, core makes iron," before discussing how the core is shrinking and about to expand again. There is a brief exchange between the speaker and an implied listener. The speaker then announces he's going to simplify the science jargon. He succinctly states "the star goes boom" and asks how big the boom is.

The clip features a male speaker, who begins by introducing a picture of the aftermath of a supernova. He mentions that there are multiple types of supernova that can be categorized into type one and type two and goes on to explain what a type one supernova does. The speaker uses a conversational tone.

The clip starts with a male speaker describing the difference between type two and type one supernovas, noting the higher hydrogen content of type twos. The speaker has a conversational tone, and expresses a sentiment of "bad news." There is one speaker.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing "a core-collapse supernova", mentioning the core collapses on itself. He then transitions to describing a "carbon detonation supernova" and explaining white dwarfs. He simplifies the concept by saying that a white dwarf in a binary system steals mass from a neighboring star, causing the core to collapse due to an increase in mass.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker describing a phenomenon where "carbon fusion begins," suggesting the content might be about astronomy or physics. His tone is informative and slightly dramatic. The speaker mentions an explosion or implosion and then identifies it as the cause of "a Type 1 Supernova". The speaker continues to speak and poses a rhetorical question: "So, what's left after a Supernova?" Lastly, there is a short period of silence.

The audio features a single male speaker discussing nebulae, describing them as remnants of stars that have detonated. He speaks in an informative and slightly playful tone, even joking about a star pulling a "chaotzu." He mentions the Crab Nebula as an example. The clip is punctuated by short moments of silence.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing an explosion, emphasizing the creation of heavy elements. He summarizes a textbook, explaining that atoms collide to form the rest of the periodic table, highlighting stellar nucleosynthesis, helium capture, and neutron capture.

The clip begins with a male speaker posing a question ("But if stars keep exploding, how do we still have new stars being created?"). He adopts a curious tone. Another male speaker responds, explaining that stars are created inside nebulae, and that nebulae come from dying stars. His tone is conversational and informative. No music or background sounds are present in the audio.

The audio starts with a man speaking in an informative tone, explaining that a star goes through its lifecycle, creates heavy elements during a supernova, and spreads dust that is then used to make new stars and planets, a process he refers to as "stellar recycling". He then addresses a person named Michael Bay in a playful tone. This is followed by upbeat synth music with a dance vibe. Then, a man shouts, "This is not okay! This needs to stop now! This is cancer!" in an increasingly frustrated and enraged tone. He repeats the word cancer several times while stating that he can feel tumors growing on his back. Finally, a loud explosive sound effect is heard.
